title: State pension age to 'hit 70 by 2050'
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Tue, Sep 1, 2015, 17:44 BST - UK Markets closed State pension age to 'hit 70 by 2050' By Andrew Oxlade | Telegraph – 2 hours 54 minutes ago 0.0000 
Official life expectancy data prompts warning of far faster rises in the state pension age 
A rise in the state pension age to 70 by 2050 is now "inevitable", a leading pension expert warned today after official data showed another sharp rise in life expectancy. 
The Government, which has already accelerated previously outlined increases in the state pension age, last year proposed a formula for future rises so that coming generations would spend "a third of their adult life in retirement". 
• State pension age: look up when you will retire 
Data published by the Office for National statistics (ONS) today showed that over the past century life expectancy at birth had increased by nearly three years per decade, up from 51 years in 1910-1912 to 79 years 100 years later, and an increase from 55 to 83 years for women. 
Around 20pc of men aged 60, and 31pc of women, can expect to survive to at least their 90th birthday. 
Malcolm McLean, senior consultant at pensions consultancy Barnett Waddingham, said: “Although no one has a crystal ball and can’t be sure for certain what the future may hold for us all, the ONS figures do raise the possibility of many more people in this country living well into their nineties by the second half of this century. 
"Using the formula now proposed by the Government that future generations should spend up to a third of their adult life in retirement it is very likely that state pension ages will have to rise much faster than currently anticipated, almost inevitably reaching at least 70 by the midpoint of the century. 
• State pension 'extinct in 30 years', warn one in six MPs 
“Longer working lives will surely become the norm for today’s younger generations, something they will have to accept in thinking ahead for retirement and how they are going to finance them.” 
Under the current timetable, the state pension age is due to reach 65 for both men and women, who currently retire earlier, in 2018. It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) will then rise to 66 by 2020 and 67 by 2028. 
An intention to increase the age to 68 in 2046 has also been suggested although the Government has said this figure will be reviewed. "The writing's on the wall," Mr McLean added. "It will rise to 68 far sooner on that based on the current projections for life expectancy." 
The "third of life" notion was first suggested in the 2013 Autumn Statement along with an intention to review the age every five years. The first of these reviews will be in 2017. 
Mr McClean said a full-scale review of the state pension was needed, if the intention was to keep increasing the pension age indefinitely. He suggested there could be a minimum pension age of 66 but with early access resulting in lower payments. 
Tom McPhail, head of pensions research at financial services firm Hargreaves Lansdown, said the figures were a warning of the need to acrue enough savings to cover ever-longer retirements. 
Making an investment pot last has also become a more pressing issue after the rules were changed to offer more pension freedoms in April. Many more people are expected to live on the income of their savings, perhaps drawing some capital, rather than commit to buying an annuity, where a saver hands over a lump sum in exchange for regular income until they die. 
Mr McPhail said: "It is vital to ensure you have made financial preparations to meet your income needs well into your third, or even your fourth decade of retirement. For many people, an annuity will continue to be the logical retirement income choice for at least part of their pension fund.” 
“If you are using drawdown to pay a retirement income then you don’t want your 90th birthday to come as an unwelcome surprise; it is essential to make sure that your income withdrawals and investment strategy remain sustainable over the long term.”
